text: Buddleja lojensis is a species endemic to the Loja region of southern Ecuador, and Piura in Peru, where it grows on mountains, savannahs and scrub, notably near streams, at elevations of 1,600 – 2,550 m.Norman, E. M. (2000). Buddlejaceae. Flora Neotropica 81. New York Botanical Garden, USA The species was first identified and described by Norman in 1982.Norman, E. M. (1982). Fl. Ecuador 16: 15, f.2, 1982. ==Description== Buddleja lojensis is a dioecious shrub 1 – 3 m tall with yellowish bark. The young branches are subquadrangular, almost glabrous, bearing subsessile ovate or lanceolate leaves 7 – 10 cm long by 2.4 – 4 cm wide, membranaceous, glabrescent above and below. The pale yellow paniculate inflorescences are 7 – 15 cm long by 4 – 9 cm wide, comprising 2 – 3 orders of leafy-bracted branches bearing small cymules of 5 – 10 flowers, the corollas 2.5 – 4 mm long. ==Cultivation== The species is not known to be in cultivation. ==References== lojensis Category:Flora of Ecuador Category:Flora of Peru Category:Flora of South America Category:Vulnerable plants Category:Taxonomy articles created by Polbot
